description: From Middle English helde, from Old English hefeld, from the root of Proto-Germanic *habjaną (“to have, heave”), from Proto-Indo-European *keh₂p-. Cognate with Old Saxon hevild, Middle Low German hevelte, Icelandic hafald.

entries.meaning: A component in a loom, being one of a number of similar components, through the eye of each of which a distinct strand of the warp is threaded.
examples: The heddles and heddle frames, Fig. 3, and the reed may be purchased from dealers in craftwork supplies.

entries.meaning: One of the sets of parallel doubled threads which, with mounting, compose the harness employed to guide the warp threads to the lathe or batten in a loom.

verbs.description: heddle (third-person singular simple present heddles, present participle heddling, simple past and past participle heddled)

entries.meaning: To thread each strand of the warp through the eye of a heddle.
examples: After each frame has been heddled, stand upright within easy reach until the full set has been completed.
